newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks close well down, eyes on New York.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks close well down, eyes on New York.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks slid to a weak close on Friday afternoon, dragged down chiefly by nervousness in the outlook for international equity markets, brokers said.
"If New York falls further, Hong Kong will fall further," said Carlton Poon, director of Hong Kong research at Worldsec International.
The Hang Seng Index closed down 269.21 points, or 2.06 percent, at 12,784.07, but off the day's low of 12,736.40. Turnover was very heavy at HK$10.10 billion, well up on Thursday's HK$8.24 billion.
"We may have been overdone (on the upside), but Hong Kong's fundamentals are reasonably promising. I'm still bullish," Poon added.
The Hang Seng Index set a record high of 13,744.30 on November 28, a 36.4 percent rise from the start of the year, Poon said.
On Thursday,the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 98.81 points to 6,303.71. The fall come in the last hour of trading and was blamed on end-session program trading.
The S&P 500 fell 11.43 points or 1.54 percent to 720.30.
But investors remained positive on the outlook for Hong Kong and other Asian markets.

"The Dow has been going through the roof for two years while Asia has lagged," said Christopher Day, joint managing director at Thornton Management (Asia) Ltd." Don't tell me the trend in Asia is set by the Dow."
Hang Seng Index futures were also weaker. The December contract fell 370 points to close at 12,760 and the January contract was down 370 points to 12,820.
"The December contract has fallen to the 50-day moving average. I think that downside is limited," said Amos Tse, head of Hong Kong sales at Mansion House Securities.
Properties led the correction, followed by property-related conglomerates in the commercial and industrial sector.
Market leaders showed the biggest net losses.
Sun Hung Kai Properties fell HK$3.00 to HK$90.75 and Henderson Land fell HK$2.50 to HK$72.00. Hutchison dropped HK$2.50 to HK$55.75.
Swire Pacific shed HK$1.50 to HK$70.75.
International banking HSBC Holdings, the most actively traded issue, slumped HK$2.00 to HK$154.50 on trade of very heavy turnover of HK$1.09 billion.
